utterances: No, you go to school for other things.
(Soundbite of laughter)
How did you end up with this specialty?
You know, I did go to film school.
I went to USC Film School.
And there, they - you know, it's a great program.
I was very happy that I had the opportunity to go there.
And I made my own films and, you know, went through that whole process.
So I'm familiar enough to know - with production to know what's going to sort of be needed.
And then you just - you know, after film school, you try to get jobs within the industry.
And I started working out through, like as a writer's assistant and up to script coordinator.
And you just work your way up like any other position as any other industry goes.
And then, just when I got this, you know, I realized I need to help the writers try to track this information because they're going to need to have this.
And would your next job, would you think, be again a script coordinator or would you be a co-producer?
I have no idea.
I guess that's up to whomever is willing to hire me and whatever title they want to give me.
Let's see if we can get one last caller in.
Gary, Gary with us from Sacramento.
Hi.

I just wanted to inject a little balance on this whole discussion by pointing out that it's only a TV show, and it's all fictional and that their creators could sit down together with a couple of quarts of good scotch one week, and they could send the story in any direction they wanted to, everywhere from killing off all the characters to turning into a - or to revealing it that it was just a Bob Newhart bad dream.
That's right.
Have they thought about that?
Oh, I have no idea.
They haven't said that to me if they have.
But I think - you know, they're pretty invested into this overall art that they're trying - and of the story that they're trying to tell.
And I think there are deeper thematic ideas that are being worked out within the episodes.
And I don't think they would necessarily do anything like that.

Is it a more satisfying program to work on - I'm sure it's more - a lot more work for one thing, but is it a more satisfying program to work on when you've got all of these loose ends lying all over the place than ""Nash Bridges"" which tied up every mystery, every episode.
You know, there were some really excellent episodes of ""Nash Bridges"" that are just fun to watch, just like any, you know, movies you go out to.
There's the mainstream movies that are fun like the ""Lethal Weapon"" ones.
And then there are the ones that give you much more material to think about and to really ponder.
And it just depends, it depends on what type of mood you're in.
We have fun episodes of ""Lost"" which are just sort of, you know, road movie episodes of ""Lost."" And then they have ones that really get into the deeper thematic elements.
And it is fun when you see the elements come together, when you see them pay off and then when you see the audience enjoy them so much.
I think that's a really great sense of satisfaction.
Gregg Nations, thanks for your time today.
Good luck.
Thank you.
Gregg Nations is co-producer, script coordinator on ""Lost."" It airs tonight and every Wednesday on ABC, joined us from the studio in Burbank.
Tomorrow on Talk of the Nation, while some executives may have to settle for half a million dollars a year, what's right, what should people make?
That's tomorrow's Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
Now in a moment, we're going to turn to the official ceremony in New York, which is going to begin with bagpipers and drummers.
I'm joined by NPR's Robert Siegel.
He's on the 10th floor of 2 World Financial Center, overlooking the National September 11th Memorial and ground zero.
Robert, tell us what we're going to see next.
But for now, what we're waiting on is the processional - the bagpipers and the drummers representing the local uniformed services of New York and New Jersey.
And Robert, I can see on - we have some TV screens here.
There are people in the audience who are holding pictures of their loved ones.
Yes.
And some have signs saying, you know, never forget - or remembering their relatives.
The audience that's in the site proper, it's only family, correct?
And the memorial is to victims all over the country on that day, both here - at 9/11 - and also in Shanksville, and also at the Pentagon.
And I want to talk a little bit more about what the memorial looks like.
From your view, I'm sure you can see - more than 400 swamp white oak trees have already been planted at the site.

But I think there's someday going to be just a very beautiful, open space in the midst of one of the most built-up places in the entire world - this lower financial and business district of New York City.
We spoke with the planner of the 9/11 site, Daniel Libeskind, who talked about his idea that this, essentially, is a place to honor memory.
And I know that - I believe the names of the victims of the attacks are etched on the lip of each of these reflecting pools.
So it's a very - I think it's - I've been able to see it from very high up, from a window up on the 34th floor on the east side of the ground zero site and now, from 10 stories up on the other side.
It's a very impressive design and should introduce a very quiet park to this part of the city.
And I have to ask, Robert, you're actually from New York.
I mean, what do these acres mean to you?
What is it like for you to see this now?
I don't think anybody thought of them the way New Yorkers think of the Empire State Building or the Chrysler building or, from an older time, the Woolworth building.
In 1993, in February, when there was an attempt to bomb....
Well - oh, go ahead, Robert.
Well, that moment, I think, they became much more loved.
Right now, I can see the pipers on their way.
We should hear them soon.
Drummers and pipers from the police department and the fire department and the Port Authority police department are marching...
And they'll be coming in with the lead World Trade Center flag, I think, and this was the flag that flew over the site until late October 2001.
This is a flag that went into space.
It went on the space shuttle Endeavor.
Right.

All of the people who were in authority in those days in New York City, New York state and New Jersey - and the United States - are here and are gathered in what is a - not just a completely nonpartisan event; it's also an entirely secular event, I might add.
You will not hear a - as far as we know, we'll not hear any prayer invocation or benediction in this event.
Nor will you hear any speeches from any of these politicians who are on stage today.
No speeches.
No speeches.
It is a ceremony of memory.
I think we can hear the drums approaching right now.
(SOUNDBITE OF DRUMMING)
These are the pipers and the drummers.
We're hearing the drummers; we should be hearing the pipers shortly.
(SOUNDBITE OF DRUMMING)
And again, you're listening to live special coverage of the 10th anniversary of the September 11th attacks.
Right now, we're listening to bagpipes and drummers who are entering the site of the ground zero September 11th Memorial.
And as Robert mentioned earlier, this is a group that's made up of police and fire, and of different members of branches of the American military.
They are walking alongside one of the pools toward the stage and in fact, they are inaugurating - right now - this memorial as they march through it.
Momentarily, we should be hearing the ""Star Spangled Banner"" and Mayor Bloomberg.
I think we can hear the pipers in the distance, can't we?
I think they're a little ways away.
A little ways off.
I know for the National Anthem, we will be hearing from the Brooklyn Youth Chorus.
They're going to be performing that.
I have a feeling that down there - we're now 10 flights up - but it's really very quiet.
Up here, of course, we are a hive of activity of all kinds of broadcast and camera crews and photographers from all over the world.
There's much attention being focused on this memorial.
But down below, I think, it must be a lot more solemn and quiet than it is up here.
It's a fascinating sight from here, I mean, to see the bagpipers and the drums.
They're marching in single file.
In kilts.
